properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Smoke from a forest fire near Sabbies River is causing a reduction in air quality due to smoke in its vicinity and areas downwind to the east and northeast. Locations: Sabbies River to Rogersville and vicinity. Short range wind forecast: Winds light and variable becoming southwest 20 km/h overnight. Wind southwest 20 Thursday. Remarks: The forest fire is still out of control from Wednesday morning and is covering an estimated area of 838 hectares as reported by New Brunswick Natural resources and Energy Development. More information will be provided as it becomes available. ### Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-05-28T16:53:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the New Brunswick Department of Environment and Local Government, the New Brunswick Department of Health, 2020-05-28T00:54:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2015216255.2020
Area: Stanley - Doaktown - Blackville Area, Kent County, Kouchibouguac National Park, Miramichi and area

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 9:43 P.M. Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a line of severe thunderstorms capable of producing very strong wind gusts, up to nickel size hail and heavy rain. This line of severe thunderstorms is moving eastward through the regions this evening. Wind gusts up to 100 kilometres per hour and heavy rain are expected with these thunderstorms. ### Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Unseasonably warm temperatures and high humidity expected for much of this week. Time span: Thursday and potentially into Friday. Maximum temperatures: Temperatures reaching or exceeding 30 degrees Celsius Thursday. Temperatures Friday reaching 24 to 29 degrees C. Locations: Southern New Brunswick (cooler temperatures for coastal communities). Remarks: Temperatures are expected to reach or exceed, 30 degrees Thursday and 24 to 29 degrees Friday. Humidex values are expected to reach the 31 to 37. A cold front will bring a return to seasonable temperatures for the start of the weekend. Heat warnings have been issued for portions of northern and central New Brunswick. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-28T16:53:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-28T00:54:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2976044756.2020
Area: Grand Lake and Queens County, Sussex - Kennebecasis Valley and Kings County, St. Stephen and Northern Charlotte County, Moncton and Southeast New Brunswick
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: First heat event of the season continues into Thursday. Maximum temperatures will be in the low thirties Thursday. Humidex values in the middle to upper thirties are forecast for Thursday. Showers and cooler temperatures are expected on Friday. ### The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-28T17:40:22-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-28T01:41:22-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3031548326.2020

properties.Title: Alberta Emergency Alert - High Water Level Alert
properties.Summary:
Description: Rising lake water is threatening areas along the Village of Alberta Beach, Summer Village of Val Quentin, and Sunset Point shorelines. This may threaten property in the area. ### Sandbags have been ordered and will be available at the Alberta Beach Public Works Building, 4000 Museum Road, by 6:00 PM. Volunteers are available to assist with some of the sand bagging activities. Listen to local community radio or follow https://www.facebook.com/albertabeach/ Facebook page or http://www.albertabeach.com/ for more information as it becomes available. Go to https://511.alberta.ca for up-to-date Road Report information.
Expires: 2020-06-03T16:56:09-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Alberta Emergency Management Agency on Behalf of the Village of Alberta Beach, 2020-05-27T16:55:43-06:00, NAADS-CA-AB-AEA1-6417
Area: Alberta Beach
properties.Author: Alberta Emergency Management Agency on Behalf of the Village of Alberta Beach

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of dangerous thunderstorms that may be capable of producing very strong wind gusts and damaging hail. The severe weather threat will end near midnight. ### Very large hail can damage property, break windows, dent vehicles and cause serious injury. Very strong wind gusts can damage buildings, down trees and blow large vehicles off the road. Intense lightning is likely with any thunderstorm that develops. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-28T07:21:13-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-28T01:54:13-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2563342435.2020
Area: Waskaganish, James Bay and La Grande River, LG Quatre - Laforge and Fontanges, Chibougamau, Manic-5 area, Sept-Îles - Port-Cartier area
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A severe thunderstorm is currently located northeast of Sandy Lake. Wind gusts up to 100 kilometres per hour have been reported at Sandy Lake and Muskrat Dam this evening. This thunderstorm may move through Sachigo Lake later this evening as it continues northeastward. ### Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Humidex values reaching 33 are expected for the next day. A period of very warm and humid weather is expected. Time span: Tonight and Thursday, possibly into Friday. Locations: northwestern New Brunswick. Minimum temperature tonight: 20 degrees C Maximum temperature Thursday: 32 degrees C (Humidex 39) Locations: Eastern New Brunswick. Maximum temperature Thursday: 32 degrees C (Humidex 39) Minimum temperature Thursday night: 18 degrees C Maximum temperature Friday: possibly 30 degree C Remarks: Warm temperatures near 30 degrees will occur Thursday with overnight temperatures near 18. Temperatures Friday will likely reach 30 degrees again on Friday. Cooler conditions will occur this weekend. ### Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-28T16:53:45-00:00

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Ice build-up due to freezing rain is expected or occurring. An area of freezing rain over northeastern Saskatchewan will shift southward impacting areas around Reindeer Lake tonight. Freezing rain will taper off by Thursday morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-28T03:59:34-00:00

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Dense fog is being observed along the north shore of Lake Superior and will remain in the area tonight into Thursday morning. The fog may become more widespread overnight and may expand eastward towards Sault St. Marie by morning. As a result, this advisory maybe expanded into these areas overnight. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
